Replies.Reply: Written by      May 29, 2012 BLACK.
OUTER SPACE, 600 KILOMETERS ABOVE-
A small metal object crosses the empty space surrounding Earth.
Orbiting at an altitude of 600 km-
Explorer, please verify that the P1 ATA removal on replacement cap part 1 and 2 are complete.
Standing by. Looks like we're on schedule. Dr. Stone, Medical is concerned about your ECG readings.
Well, medical doesn't agree doctor.
That's a date, doctor. Just remember, Houston is partial to Margaritas.
Negative. We're not seeing any data.
Standing by.
Please expand.
Tijuana. You've told this story, Kowalsky. As Houston recalls, she took off in your '74 GTO. Engineering requests fuel status on the jet pack prototype.
Engineering says thank you.
We know the Corvette story, Matt.
Especially engineering. We're going to miss you, Matt.
Thank you doctor. Shariff, what's your status?
Could you be more specific?
Hubble Telescope engaged. Upgrade fully functional. That applause you hear is for you, Shariff.
Matt, please advise as to Mission Specialist Shariff's current activity.
Dr. Stone. Houston. Medical now have you with a temperature drop to 35.9 and heart rate rise to 70.
Doctor Stone? Medical is asking if you want to return to Explorer?
That's a negative. I'm afraid we're getting nothing on this end, doctor.
Still nothing.
Kowalsky?
Negative.
We're not receiving any data.
That seems to be the case. Engineering admits that you warned us that this could happen. That's as close to an apology as you're going to get from them. We should've listened to you doc.
Copy that. How long do you think it'll take you?
Outstanding. We appreciate your patience, Doctor. Installing your system in the Hubble is the main purpose of this mission.
Matt, It's been a privilege.
Permission granted.
Explorer, this is Houston.

NORAD reports a satellite has incurred a missile strike. The impact has created a cloud of debris orbiting at 20,000 miles per hour. Current debris orbit does not overlap with your trajectory. We'll keep you posted on any developments.
You're the expert, doctor. It's your call.
Please elaborate.
That is affirmative. Surprisingly, control hasn't heard the Mardi Gras story. Please proceed.
ISS, this is Houston.
Explorer, this is Houston.
Mission abort. Repeat: mission abort.
Begin re-entry procedure. Start Deorbit Prep for PLS at Kennedy. ISS, initiate emergency evacuation.

Debris from the impact has caused a chain reaction, hitting other satellites in its path and creating new debris. Norad reports that orbital and ballistic effects are driving the cloud of debris up toward your altitude. How copy?
We have a full on chain reaction. It's been confirmed that it is the unintentional side effect of the Russians striking one of their own satellites.
Explorer, new data coming through.
It's not good. Most of our systems are going down. Debris chain reaction is out of control and rapidly expanding.
Most of them. Telecomunications systems are gone. Expect a communication blackout at any moment.
You're a go for TH1138. Repeat You're a go for TH1138 procedure.
DMA M1, M2, M3 and M4 are complete.
Go ahead Houston.
Standby for arm maneuver.
Standby for marking.
Go ahead Houston.
Copy all Houston, and in work.
Airlock engaged--ready to receive.
Kowalsky, initiate emergency disconnect from the Hubble.
Copy that Houston.
You are a go, Kowalsky.
Houston, this is Explorer. Copy?
Houston, this is Explorer. Copy?
We lost Houston!
Installation ninety-five percent complete. Running level one diagnostics on circuits, sensors, and power. Standby.
I'm fine Houston.
Not any more than usual, Houston.
Houston, please confirm reception of data.
Stand by, Houston. I'm gonna reboot the comm card.
Comm card reboot in progress.
No, we've been here for a week Houston, let's just finish this.
Try again.
Houston, could you please turn that music off?
Thank you, Kowalsky.
Now, Houston?
Could Houston be misinterpreting the data--?
Mmmm. Let me see what's going on.
What have you got here?
Visual examination doesn't reveal any damaged components. The problem must be originating in the comms panel.
I'm on it.
An hour.
Assistance appreciated.
Certainly.
Like a Chihuahua that's being tumble dried.
Thanks. Sorry. In my basement lab things usually fall to the floor.
Call me a genius if I can get this board initialized in the next hour.
Should we be worried?
Explorer, engage arm and pivot to cargo bay.
I was just happy that they didn't cut the funding to my research.
Six months.
Assuming it works, it's just for hospital use. This one is a prototype.
My eyes are brown.
Mm-hm.
The silence.
I could get used to it.
Houston, from first inspection comms panel appears to be dead. Am I a go to cut link to auxiliary?
Proceeding to over ride.
I can't. If I turn it off now we'll lose the whole system.
Sorry. I'm sorry. It's done.
Kowalsky, visual of debris at nine o'clock.
Dr. Stone requesting faster, faster transport.
Dr. Stone requesting faster transport to the bay area. Explorer get me down.
It's stuck!
Nooooo!
No.
I can't!
Ok. Ok.
I'm trying. I'm trying.
Ok. I'm trying! I can't it's stuck, Hold on.
Yes. Yes. I copy. I'm detached!
I don't know. I don't know! I'm spinning. I can't. I can't.
I told you! Nothing. I see nothing!
It's too fast.
Houston, this is Dr. Ryan Stone.. I'm drifting but I have a visual of Explorer.
With North at 12 o'clock, the Shuttle is at the center of the dial.
I can see the Chinese station. No, no, no, it's the International Space Station.
ISS is at 6, no, 7 o'clock.
Lieutenant Kowalsky, do you copy?
Explorer, do you copy?
Houston, do you copy?
Houston, this is Mission Specialist Ryan Stone. I'm off structure and I'm drifting.
Do you copy?
YES! YES! I copy! I'm here!
My light?
Here! Here!
3.6 psi, I think.
Copy.
Please hurry.
Oh. Sorry.
Arghh!
Okay. Okay. Okay. Okay, Ohh I got it.
Nooooooo!!!! Dammit!!!
Ahh Dammit!
Ahhh Dammit.
Why aren't they answering?
Can they hear us on an alternate frequency?
Why ninety?
02 down to six percent.
Yeah. Pretty scary shit.
Where is he? Where is he?
Oh, my God. Oh, my God.
I'm trying. I'm trying.
I got him. I got him.
02 down to five percent.
I apologize for not complying. I should've stopped working as soon as you instructed me to.
Yes?
Agreed.
02 down to two percent.
What?
Home?
Lake Zurich.
Illinois.
I had a daughter.
When I received the call I was driving and ever since that's what I do. I wake up, I go to work and then I just drive.
02 down to one percent.
Uhuh?
I got it. I got it.
The tether broke. I'm detached. I'm I'm detached.
I've got you. I've got you--
No. No. No. Don't you. No. Don't you.
Gotcha!
What? No--
No!
I'm not letting you go! We're fine.
Please don't do this.
Please don't do this. Please don't do this.
No!
I had you! I had you.
My CO2 alarm went off. My CO2 alarm went off.
Yes. Yes. I see it. I see it.
Yes.
Ok.
I've never flown a Shenzhou--
Ok.
Only on a simulator.
I crashed it. I--
Every time. I crashed the Simulator every time.
I'm going to take the Soyuz and come get you.
No. I'm coming to get you.
Dad wanted a boy.
Not yet.
What?
What?
Matt!
Come on, come on.
OK. Where are you? Where are you?
Matt. This is Ryan. Copy?
Matt. This is Ryan. Copy?
Come on Matt. Talk to me.
Tell me where you are.
Oh, come on. You've been yammering nonstop since we left Cape Canaveral, and now you decide to shut up?
Come on Matt, talk to me!
Tell me about Mardi Gras. Tell me about the hairy guy. What happened?
Oh Matt. I'm not ready for this.
Houston in the blind.
To confirm, I--Ryan Stone--am the sole survivor of STS-157.
What now?
We don't have four minutes to spare.
Rezerv rasstyk!
I engaged manual control- R O A K and RYD are activated.
Oh, no. No, no, no.
Great. Fantastic. Perfect.
Clear skies but with a chance of satellite debris.
Okay. We detach this and we go home.
Oh shit.
Shit!
I hate space.
Shut up!
Ok.
Alright. That's good.
Okay, let's stabilise you.
Ok. Let's visit the Chinese station.
Ok.
Come on. Come on!
You gotta be kidding me.
Where's your backup?
Where's your goddamn backup?!
This is Dr Ryan Stone, can you hear me? Houston, this is Ryan Stone, can you hear me? Copy? Houston, this is Ryan Stone, can you hear me? Copy?
Houston, this is Ryan Stone, can you hear me? Copy? Houston, this is Ryan Stone, can you hear me? Copy?
Houston. Houston! This is Mission Specialist Ryan Stone. Do you copy!
Houston, you're coming in over the AM frequency. Please confirm identity.
Repeat. This is Mission Specialist Ryan Stone from STS-157. Do you copy?
Is this the Chinese Station? Is this Tiangong? Copy?
Do you speak English?
S.O.S. Do you understand?
Mayday! Can you copy? Mayday! Mayday!
Yes! Mayday! Mayday!
Aningang?
No, Mayday's not my name. I'm Stone, Dr. Ryan Stone-- I need help.
Are those dogs? Those are dogs! Are you calling from Earth?!
Where are you, Aningang? Is the sun out? Are there birds? Are there trees?
Is it beautiful where you are? Here it's colder than hell and lonelier than shit, but it's beautiful Aningang. Utterly, terrifyingly beautiful.
Make your dogs bark again, Aningang.
Dogs! Woof. Woof. Woof.
Woof. Woof.
I'm going to die, Aningang.
I mean, we're all going to die.
Funny that. To know.
A baby. There's a baby with you.
You are singing to your baby? Is that a lullaby? That's so sweet!
I used to sing to my baby too.
I hope I see her soon.
How did you?
But how did you?
How?
You never told me where.
No.
We can't.
There's no fuel. I tried everything.
I tried everything.
They're for landing so.
I never got to land the simulator, I told you.
And I crashed it every time.
How did you get here?
What?
Landing, landing. Landing is launching.
Okay, landing, landing, landing is green.
Okay, okay landing, alright.
Listen to me Matt. You're going to see a girl with brown hair. She's Sarah, her hair is probably a mess. That's okay, she doesn't like to brush it.
Tell her mommy found her red shoe. She was so upset about that shoe Matt, but tell her it was right under the bed.
Okay Houston, here comes the tricky part, the Soyuz has to think we're only three meters above the earth.
Let's reset you then.
Okay. I only have one shot at this.
What's the point if we don't try?
You're losing altitude, Tiangong. You keep dropping and you're going to kiss the atmosphere. But not before I get to you. You have my last ride home.
Okay, I'm done with just driving.
Ahhhhhh!
Come on. Come on.
Seriously?
No hablo chino.
This is Mission Specialist Ryan Stone reporting from the Shenzhou. I'm about to undock from the Tiangong and I have a bad feeling about this mission.
Reminds me of a story, Houston--
It's getting hotter in here.
Whichever way it goes, no harm no foul.
Because either way--
It'll be one hell of a ride.
I'm ready.
Yeehaaa!
Ahhhhhhhh!
AAAHHHHHH!
Thank you.
Ahhhhh!!!
Houston, I have a bad feeling about this mission.
Engineering. Except for a slight malfunction on the nulling of the roll axis, this jetpack is one prime piece of thrust.
Tell them I still prefer my '67 Corvette though. Speaking of which did I ever tell you the--
Even Engineering?
He appears to be doing the Macarena of some sort. Though that would merely be a best guess scenario on my part.
Not a problem.
Seventy-five minutes shy. Never crossed my mind.
Right back atcha, Houston.
Am I a go to assist Dr. Stone in removing the panel?
Thank you, Houston.
Mind if I join the fun?
How are you feeling?
It's been a rough week. If it makes you feel any better, I puked up everything but my kidneys on my first ride.
Hey -- you're the genius up here. I just drive this bus.
Let the boys down there worry for us.
So doc, now that you work for NASA, how do you like it?
How long was your training?
So, what is this scanning system?
Listen, they don't bankroll prototypes, even for your pretty blue eyes.
Right now your eyes are blood shut.
And to think he went to Harvard.
"Mmm?" So what do you like about being up here?
Hmmmm. Terrific.
Houston, I have a bad feeling about this mission.
Then all of a sudden I look up and --

I am about to yell out when I notice she's holding hands with a short hairy guy in board shorts and a Margaritaville T-shirt. Then I realize, the guy's no guy. My sister's friend is holding hands with a--
Roger. Explorer, prep airlock!
Houston. Elaborate.
Copy all Houston.
Put a bow on it Dr. Stone.
I'm not going to ask you again.
Not one second. Now! Shut it down!
Alright Shariff, let's do this.
Houston. Update.
Right of disposal. Most likely a spy sat gone bad. Now it's space junk.
Explorer, ready to disengage HST.
What's the blowback, Houston?
Define "multiple" sats.
Half of North America just lost their Facebook.
Explorer, this is Kowalsky. Confirming visual contact with debris. Debris is from a BSE sat. To repeat--
To repeat I have-
We have to go. Go, go! Go!
Explorer permission to retrieve Dr.
Unstrap! You can't tune out the world up here.
Try releasing the safety clip.
No, don't wait for us. Get inside.
Man down! Man down!
Disengage!!!
Explorer has been hit. Explorer do you read? Explorer, over. Explorer--
Astronaut off structure! Dr. Stone is off structure!
Dr. Stone, detach!
You must detach!
If you don't detach that arm is going to carry you too far!
Listen to my voice. You need to focus.
You need to detach. I can't see you anymore.
Do it. Now!
Houston, I've lost visual of Dr.
Dr. Stone! Do you copy?! Repeat! Do you copy?
Report your position.
Give me a visual.
Do you have a visual of Explorer?
Do you have a visual of ISS?
Repeat. Do you copy?
Flash your light.
So I can see you.
There you are. Hang tight. Report your status.
Your status! Give me your readings?
Your O2. Give me your O2.
You're breathing too fast. You're burning oxygen. We don't want to do that. We want to relax. Copy.
Nearly there.
You can holster that torch, Dr. Stone.
Gotcha.
Now, I'm going to tether you to me.
I know. You never realized how devastatingly good-looking I am.
But I need you to stop staring and help me with the tether. Okay?
Ok. So far so good. Now listen. I'm going to give you a little push, just so you're clear of the jets--
Sorry. Not a push, more like a nudge.
See? Where you go, I go.
Better. Let's get out of here.
I know what you mean.
You're burning oxygen, we're going to go back to the shuttle. How's that for a plan. Copy?
Right copy that.
Houston this is Kowalsky. How do you copy?
It seems like communications are lost.
We don't know. That's why we keep talking. If someone is listening they might just save your life. Set your watch for ninety minutes.
Houston clocked that debris at fifty thousand miles per hour. Factoring in our current orbit, I reckon we've got 90 minutes before we play duck and cover again.
Okay. Pretty scary shit being untethered up here, isn't it?
You did all right.

Houston, in the blind. This is Kowalsky. Our current location is approximately 900 meters out from the Explorer. Dr. Stone and I would like to retrieve the body of Mission Specialist Shariff and return it to Shuttle. Am I a go to retrieve?
Roger that.
Grab him!
Quick. You're pulling me away.
Clutch him like he's your Valentine. I can't gauge my thrust with you two yo-
All right, here we go. Careful of the edges.
Houston, in the blind. To confirm.
We were going to be hit no matter what. There was nothing you could've done to change that.
Hey.
It's our best option. Agreed?
Agreed?
Alright. After you.
Houston in the blind, this is Kowalsky. Dr. Stone and I have determined to proceed to ISS and use one of their Soyuz for re-entry. ISS if copy, please send rescue mission.
We're getting there.
Beautiful, don't you think?
The sunrise. That's what I'm going to miss the most.
So, where's home, Dr. Stone?
Ryan. Where's home?
Ah ha. Down there. Mother Earth. Where do you pitch your tent?
Where the hell is that?
What would you be doing?
There we go. Let me guess. NPR?
What do you miss down there?
Is there a Mr. Stone?
Nobody special? Someone down there, looking up, thinking of you?
What was her name?
Well, well, what d'you know. I have good news and bad news.
What?
The tank may be empty but there's still oxygen in your suit, so sip, Ryan. Don't gulp. It's wine, not beer.
Let's go.

Houston in the blind we have visual of the ISS. Station must have been evacuated because first Soyuz is missing. Second Soyuz exhibits surface damage and chute has deployed. It's use as escape pod for re-entry to Earth is impossible.
I can't. Can's empty. We're coming in fast and we're going to hit hard. Grab onto anything you can and hold tight!
Grab a hold. Grab anything.
You have to let me go.
You have to.
Those ropes are too loose, I'm pulling you with me. You have to let me go or we both die--
Ryan!
It's not up to you.
You're going to make it Ryan.
Ryan do you copy? Do you copy?
You need to board the station. Can you see the airlock?
Good. That's where you want to go.
That's because you're breathing CO2 and you're losing consciousness. You need to board the Station.
Move!
Now listen to me. That second Soyuz is too damaged for re-entry, but it's perfectly fine for a little Sunday drive.
That doesn't matter. Its re-entry protocol is identical to the Soyuz's--
You've never flown a Soyuz either.
So then you know.
It's a Simulator. That's what it's designed for.
It's not rocket science. Just point the damn thing at earth and by this time tomorrow you'll be back in Lake Zurich with one hell of a story to tell. You copy? Ryan. You copy?
No you're not. . I have too much of a head start. That ship already sailed.
Ryan, you're going to have to learn to let go.
I want to hear you say you're going to make it.
Ryan! Say it!
Alright. Keep going  Ryan stares at Matt's tiny figure in the distance.
What kind of name is Ryan for a girl?
Are you close to the airlock?
Keep going.
So, now that we have some distance between us- you're attracted to me, aren't you?
Well, people say I have beautiful blue eyes.
You wanna know the good news?
I'm going to break Anatoly's record, and I think mine's going to stand for a long, long time.
You know, Ryan is a nice name for a girl. Wow, you should see the sun on the Ganges. It's amazing.
Ahhhh! Alright, check your watch. 13 hours, 11 minutes. Call Anatoly, tell him he's been bumped.
light?
Trust me, it's a hell of a story.
That's better.
I found a little extra battery power.
No? Right, let's get out of here.
Chinese Station. A little Sunday drive.
Course we can.
Well, there's always something we can do.
Did you try the soft landing jets?
Well landing is launching it's the same thing, didn't you learn about that in training?
But you know about it.
Listen you want to go back or do you want to stay here? I get it, it's nice up here, you can just shut down all the systems turn out all the lights, and just close your eyes and tune out everybody.
There's nobody up here who can hurt you, it's safe. Then what's the point in going on, what's the point of living?

Your kid died, doesn't get any rougher than that, but still it's a matter of what you do now. If you decide to go that you've gotta just get on with it, sit back enjoy the ride. You have to start living life, Ryan.
It's time to go home.
Nearly there. Replacing battery module A1 and C.
Kinda like winning the lottery, isn't it?
Including holidays?
Nothing rad, it's just a new set of eyes to scan the universe.
Kowalsky!
Is this great or what?!
Roger.
They shot down their own satellite?
Heads up!
Need some help there Matt?
She DROPS IT.
Brings Shariff to an ABRUPT STOP, snapping him back like a bungee cord.
THE EARTH, with its ever-changing surface of blues and whites, greens and browns, is massive and serene below him.
Zlotze Houston.
Ryan's panic grows as she spins further into the nothingness of space.
As Matt's signal grows fainter her breathing becomes more labored.
Ryan can see her face reflected against the visor, lit by the control panels.
A LIGHT, not bigger than a star, is FLICKERING.
The cabin has been destroyed. A disarray of objects, smashed and devastated.
THE SUN looks brighter and clearer than ever outside of Earth's atmosphere. The oceans and the continents brighten as its light spills over the Earth beneath them.
Which is half a mile away, and now all of its modules are clearly visible. It also becomes clear that-
SHE STOPS.
Ryan grabs the tether. It slides through her closed fist, until-
SHE PULLS HERSELF UP, and clinging with her leg, she secures herself to the panel.
Matt rolling, drifting in her direction.
Do you copy?
The Station hovers below the Soyuz like a large whale swimming beneath a tiny lifeboat.
Nothing more than a dot.
In the vacuum of space there was nothing to carry sound waves, but now sound begins to travel through the oxygen that slowly fills the cabin.
And pushes it from her head.
UNITY NODE 1.
ZARYA MODULE.
ZVEZDA MODULE.
SOYUZ. AIRLOCK.
The Destiny Lab begins blinking.
She pushes herself toward the hatch, swimming through the few pieces of paper still hovering as she exits into the-
Dashing straight into the-
She darts across the module, behind her-
Just in time. Above her, the flames cross the Node as they spread into the rest of the Station.
The distance between the Soyuz and the Docking Module grows little by little as the vessel drifts away from it.
The Station is drifting out of the scope's sight.
Where the western horizon comes into frame and nears the center crosshair.
The Soyuz is approaching the Tiangong. The center of the crosshair is aiming three degrees above the Chinese Station.
The Chinese Station quickly grows in size as the Soyuz gets closer and closer.
And through the glass she sees that-
The parachute is tangled with a solar panel and the ropes are tensing up, and-
The rope extends from the cabin to the parachute tangled with the Station.
THROUGH THE GLASS, the helmet of an astronaut is looking in.
The Chinese Station is approaching, getting closer.
A thin bright yellow halo covers the whole window.
A blinding light pours in from outside the window.
The SOFT JETS ignite, launching the vessel upwards.
An impact has blown open the cover. Three ropes float out of the container into space. Three meters away from the vessel each rope branches into dozens of parachute strings. Next to it-
OUTER SPACE. 300 KM ABOVE EARTH.
Hannic ya itcitem pini!
Uumaruq taigaa!
Mayday!
Mayday! Aningang!
Mayday, Aningang! Aningang, Mayday!
Aningang! Mayday! Suli, suli!
Mayday! Ieukpalliktuq uumaruq taigaa naabuqtuq.
Ieukpalliktuq naabuqtuq.
Auuu. Auuu. Oipmiq. Oipmiq! Auuu.
Auuu. Auuu. Woof. Woof.
The Oxygen in the cabin's atmosphere begins to drop.
An ILLUSTRATION of the Soyuz Capsule two meters before landing and hitting the ground. A thrust is shooting out from under its bottom, cushioning its fall: THE SOFT LANDING ENGINES.
THE SOYUZ BURNING upon contact with the atmosphere.
It acts like a thrust that pushes her toward the Station. It helped, but she is still off target.
Propelling herself even closer to the Station.
But only a very SMALL THRUST comes out of the extinguisher, not enough to push her on the right track.
The LIFEBOAT, the SHENZHOU, a vessel very similar to the Soyuz, is docked on a module.
She slowly drifts across the modules, the tips of her fingers almost touching the surface of the Tiangong.
A solar panel, following the rotation of the Station, comes into view.
A LONESOME PIECE OF DEBRIS.
Clusters of DEBRIS pass by, flying at different distances and at great speeds.
THE PARACHUTE IS GETTING CLOSER, a net about to trap her.
The red, yellow, and green graph is bright red. Under it, TWO BUTTONS with Chinese ideograms on them.
Her finger hesitates as she takes a wild guess.
A FAINT HISSING SOUND is heard.
She's in pain and more tired than ever now, and she's punchy.
She waits, floating.
She enters the hatch into the-
A Docking Module, very similar to the one in the ISS. At the far end of it an open hatch leads into the SHENZHOU ESCAPE POD.
An ALARM RINGS, and under the ongoing LOOP, a RECORDING, clearly warning.
AND PULLS IT.
THE CABIN separates from the rest of the vessel and from the Station. It spins away, plummeting toward the atmosphere.
THE CEILING- where condensation is dripping.
THE LANDING ENGINES IGNITE, giving the downward thrust meant to cushion the landing on a hard surface.
Making a wave that spreads out in a circle.
The metallic capsule, which weighs almost three tons, sinks quickly into the lake. As the ropes of the parachute tense, the long fabric follows the cabin down.
THE SHENZHOU HITS THE LAKE BOTTOM.
OUTER SPACE, but-
She SWIMS, breaking through the water and harnessing every last bit of energy in her.
She drags herself from the water, like the first amphibious life form crawling out of the primordial soup onto land.
ANOTHER FOOT.
